title.value: Interpret Your Care: Predicting the Evolution of Symptoms for Cancer Patients
title.justification: This is the exact title of the paper as mentioned by the user.
title.quote: Interpret Your Care: Predicting the Evolution of Symptoms for Cancer Patients

extractions.description: This paper focuses on predicting the evolution of pain and tiredness levels in cancer patients using an interpretable decision tree-based model called LightGBM. The study specifically addresses class imbalance using the oversampling technique of SMOTE. The dataset used consists of real-world patient data from 2013 to 2019, covering 20163 patients. The results indicate that previous symptom levels are key indicators for prediction.

type.justification: The study involves the implementation and evaluation of machine learning models on real-world data, thus focusing on empirical analysis.
type.quote: In this paper, we use patient data to predict the evolution of their symptoms such that treatment-related impairments can be prevented or effects meaningfully ameliorated.

name.justification: The study's focus on predicting symptoms in cancer patients places it within the healthcare domain.
name.quote: Clinical providers and other decision makers in healthcare note interpretability of model predictions as a priority for implementation and utilization.

name.justification: The study uses machine learning models, specifically decision tree-based models like LightGBM, for predicting symptoms.
name.quote: To this end, we use DTs for prediction as each decision point can be visualised individually by clinicians.

name.justification: The primary model used in this study is LightGBM, which is explicitly mentioned multiple times.
name.quote: In this paper we, therefore, propose an interpretable pipeline for predicting the level of two different symptoms, i.e. pain and tiredness levels, using LightGBM (Ke et al. 2017), a decision tree (DT) based model which is widely used for its efficiency and interpretability.

is_contributed.justification: The LightGBM model was not contributed by this paper but was used from existing literature.
is_contributed.quote: ...using LightGBM (Ke et al. 2017), a decision tree (DT) based model.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed for the experiments described in the paper.
is_executed.quote: For predicting each symptom (pain and tiredness), we consider two variants of LightGBM models.

is_compared.justification: The performance of the LightGBM model was compared against baseline models like Naive Prior (NP) and Previous Value (PV).
is_compared.quote: We compare the performance of the LightGBM models with two baselines models. We refer to these baselines as NP and PV for naive prior and previous value, respectively.

referenced_paper_title.value: LightGBM: A Highly Efficient Gradient Boosting Decision Tree
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the paper referenced for the LightGBM model used.
referenced_paper_title.quote: using LightGBM (Ke et al. 2017), a decision tree (DT) based model

name.justification: The dataset consists of real-world patient data collected from 2013 to 2019, covering 20163 patients.
name.quote: Our aim is to leverage previously collected patient reported data to predict the evolution of a patientâ€™s symptoms... We have access to a dataset of real cases collected for years 2013-2019 on 20163 patients.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper; the dataset is described as being collected from real-world patient data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We have access to a dataset of real cases collected for years 2013-2019 on 20163 patients.

name.justification: SMOTE is explicitly used for addressing the class imbalance in the dataset.
name.quote: we rely on Synthetic Minority Oversampling TEchnique (SMOTE) (Chawla et al. 2002) to address class imbalance by generating synthetic samples.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper for SMOTE mentioned in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we rely on Synthetic Minority Oversampling TEchnique (SMOTE) (Chawla et al. 2002)
